title: A Novel Rescue Technique for Difficult Intubation and Difficult Ventilation
procedures:
An endotracheal tube size appropriate for the patient's age for endotracheal intubation should be chosen. We use the formula: ETT size = age(yr)/4 +4.
We chose a one size smaller uncuffed endotracheal tube to be inserted nasally, in case the endotracheal intubation fails after the patient is put to sleep.
Before nasal insertion of the tube, we measure the approximate distance from the nose to the level of the vocal cords, which is usually at the level of mid thyroid cartilage.
After the patient is anesthetized, and after a failed endotracheal intubation attempt and failed ventilation, the well lubricated one size smaller endotracheal tube will be inserted nasally to a level just above the vocal cords.
One has to ensure a good seal of the mouth and nares of the patient. The anesthesia circuit can be attached to the ET tube connector, and with appropriate seal of the mouth and the nose, the lungs can be adequately ventilated.
After sealing the nose and the mouth, lungs are adequately ventilated as confirmed by ETCO2 waveform, chest rising of the patient and good oxygen saturation on pulse oximeter.Subscription Required. Please recommend JoVE to your librarian.
